meanings.definition: To subtract or take away from a total.
meanings.sent1: I will deduct five dollars from your allowance for not completing your chores.
meanings.sent2: Remember to deduct the cost of shipping from the final price.
meanings.sent3: If you deduct too much, you might end up owing money instead!
meanings.sent4: She deducts time spent on breaks as time worked, making her more productive.
meanings.sent5: In order to save money, always deduct unnecessary expenses from your budget.

meanings.definition: To derive by reasoning or inference.
meanings.sent1: From the evidence presented, we can deduct that the suspect was at the scene of the crime.
meanings.sent2: Scientists deduct conclusions based on data collected during experiments.
meanings.sent3: You can deduct that it's going to rain soon by looking at the dark clouds.
meanings.sent4: By observing the behavior of the animals, we can deduct their natural habitat.
meanings.sent5: The detective was able to deduct the identity of the thief from the fingerprints left at the crime scene.

meanings.definition: To withhold or remove from salary or wages.
meanings.sent1: The company will deduct taxes from your paycheck before you receive it.
meanings.sent2: Don't forget to deduct any unpaid leave days from your salary this month.
meanings.sent3: He jokingly said he would deduct a dollar from his friend's salary for being late.
meanings.sent4: The boss decided to deduct a portion of the bonus for not meeting the sales target.
meanings.sent5: It's common for employers to deduct contributions for health insurance from employees' wages.
